container-title: Nationalism

Banti on how the Italian nation was imagined in the nineteenth century has been especially fruitful. For a debate about his cultural reading of Risorgimento nationalism, see the essays in the journal Nations and Nationalism
title: The 1980s and 1990s saw intense general discussions around the issues of state- and nation-building and national identity. Many of the key works contain some consideration of the Italian case. These include: John Breuilly, Nationalism and the State
Benedict Anderson, Imagined Communities
Nations and Nationalism since 1789: Programme, Myth, Reality
Adrian Hastings, The Construction of Nationhood: Ethnicity, Religion and Nationalism
For Italy, the work of the Italian historian Alberto M
For a general history of modern Italy built around the theme of state- and nation-building, see Christopher Duggan, The Force of Destiny: a History of Italy since 1796

note: The Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip II
title: For a survey of the main geographical features of Italy
A Geography of Italy
Italy: a Geographical Introduction

note: see Emilio Sereni, History of the Italian Agricultural Landscape (Princeton University Press, 1997). For the history of the Italian language, see Bruno Migliorini and Thomas Griffith, The Italian Language
title: For the material and human constraints in relation to industrialisation, see Russell King, The Industrial Geography of Italy

remains fundamental still for an understanding of the alliance with Nazi Germany. An important study of the territories occupied by Italy in the war is D

note: For a general thematic introduction to post-war Italy, see P.
title: The best general history in English of the so-called ‘First Republic’, focusing on the limitations of the state in meeting the needs of a fast-changing society, is P. Ginsborg, A History of Contemporary Italy: Society and Politics 1943–1988
This can be supplemented by the same author’s account of the breakdown of the ‘First Republic’: Italy and its Discontents: Family, Civil Society, State 1980–2001
